verses.text: A copy of the letter which Jeremiah sent to those who were to be taken captive to Babylon by Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, as commanded by God.
verses.comment: This introduction frames the text as Jeremiah’s letter to Babylonian exiles, paralleling Jeremiah 29, thus grounding Baruch 6 (the 'Epistle of Jeremiah') within the context of Israel’s Babylonian captivity by divine decree.
verses.sectionHeader: The Exile and Promise of Return

verses.text: Because of the sins that you have committed before God, you will be led away captive to Babylon by Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon.
verses.comment: The deportation to Babylon is directly attributed to Israel’s sin, reflecting a recurring theme in the prophets—exile as divine judgment (cf. 2 Kings 24:10-16; Jer 25:8-11).

verses.text: You will remain there for many years, for a long time, up to seven generations; but after that I will bring you back from there in peace.
verses.comment: The prediction of a lengthy exile—‘up to seven generations’—underscores God’s sovereignty over history and offers hope for restoration, resonating with Jeremiah’s promise of return after seventy years (Jer 29:10).

verses.text: Now in Babylon you will see gods made of silver and gold and wood, which people carry on their shoulders, and which cause the nations to fear.
verses.comment: Baruch warns of Babylonian idols—crafted images venerated by the nations—preparing the exiles for the challenge of remaining faithful amidst pervasive idolatry, echoing polemics in Isaiah 44:9-20 and Psalm 115:4-8.

verses.text: So beware of becoming at all like the foreigners or of letting fear for these gods possess you.
verses.comment: Highlights the false honor given to idols. True worship is reserved for God alone (Psalm 96:5).

verses.text: When you see the crowd before and behind them worshiping them, say in your hearts, 'It is you, O Lord, whom we must worship.'
verses.comment: Israel is exhorted to worship God alone inwardly despite external pressure, highlighting the theme of inner fidelity and recalling the Shema (Deut 6:4-5) and Daniel’s resistance in exile (Dan 3, 6).

verses.text: For my angel is with you, and he is watching over your lives.
verses.comment: God’s assurance of angelic protection for the exiles reflects a persistent biblical motif (cf. Dan 3:28; Psalm 91:11), emphasizing divine presence and care in foreign lands.

verses.text: Their tongues are smoothed by the carpenter, and they themselves are overlaid with gold and silver; but they are false and cannot speak.
verses.comment: Scepters symbolize authority, but the idols lack any true power. Points to the impotence of man-made ‘gods’.

verses.text: People take gold and make crowns for the heads of their gods, as they might for a girl who loves ornaments.
verses.comment: Idols are powerless even to protect themselves; only God is a true defense.

verses.text: Sometimes the priests secretly take gold and silver from their gods and spend it on themselves,
verses.comment: Shows the maintenance devoted to idols contrasts with the living God’s self-sufficiency.

verses.text: or even give some of it to the prostitutes on the terrace. They deck their gods out with garments like human beings—these gods of silver and gold and wood
verses.comment: Underscores idols’ complete dependency upon humans, affirming the uniqueness of the living God.

verses.text: that cannot save themselves from rust and corrosion. When they have been dressed in purple robes,
verses.comment: Relates idol worship to necromancy, the worship of the dead. Emphasizes spiritual lifelessness.

verses.text: their faces are wiped because of the dust from the temple, which is thick upon them.
verses.comment: Shows how idols’ possessions are reused—no sanctity is recognized, unlike true worship reserved for God.

verses.text: One of them holds a scepter, like a district judge, but is unable to destroy anyone who offends it.
verses.comment: Purple symbolizes royalty, yet the idols remain powerless. Contrasts with Christ’s true kingly authority.

verses.text: Another has a dagger in its right hand, and an ax, but cannot defend itself from war and robbers.
verses.comment: Stresses the irony of reverence for powerless idols; points to the need for worship of the true God.

verses.text: From this it is evident that they are not gods; so do not fear them.
verses.comment: The fragility of idols highlights their impotence; points to God’s eternal stability.

verses.text: For just as someone's dish is useless when it is broken,
verses.comment: Alludes to God as the giver of breath and life, which Christ also restores in His resurrection (cf. John 20:22).

verses.text: so are their gods when they have been set up in the temples. Their eyes are full of the dust raised by the feet of those who enter. And just as the gates are shut on every side against anyone who has offended a king, as though under sentence of death, so the priests make their temples secure with doors and locks and bars, in order that they may not be plundered by robbers.
verses.comment: Idols lack reason or agency. Genuine reverence belongs only to the divine.

verses.text: They light more lamps for them than they light for themselves, though their gods can see none of them.
verses.comment: Once again, human effort is required to maintain idols, unlike the Lord who upholds all things.

verses.text: They are just like a beam of the temple, but their hearts, it is said, are eaten away when crawling creatures from the earth devour them and their robes. They do not notice
verses.comment: Biblical theme: idols are powerless. All good comes from the living God.

verses.text: when their faces have been blackened by the smoke of the temple.
verses.comment: Again, idol worship parallels necromancy. Also critiques religious commercialization.

verses.text: Bats, swallows, and birds alight on their bodies and heads; and so do cats.
verses.comment: Idols receive tribute reserved for living beings, highlighting their impotence.

verses.text: From this you will know that they are not gods; so do not fear them.
verses.comment: Contrasts the enduring presence of God with idols repurposed for human use.

verses.text: As for the gold that they wear for beauty—it will not shine unless someone wipes off the tarnish; for even when they were being cast, they did not feel it.
verses.comment: The cycle of giving then taking back shows the emptiness of idol worship.

verses.text: They are bought without regard to cost, but there is no breath in them.
verses.comment: Idols are blind; contrasts with Christ as the light of the world (John 8:12).

verses.text: Like one in the palace whom the king honors, the idol is carried about, though it cannot move itself.
verses.comment: Idols receive ceremonial honor, but lack the king’s authority and life.

verses.text: If it falls to the ground, someone must pick it up; if set upright, it cannot move itself.
verses.comment: Reiterates the powerlessness of idols, only God sustains Himself and His creation.

verses.text: The priests sell the sacrifices that are offered to these gods and use the money themselves. Likewise their wives preserve some of the meat with salt, but give none to the poor or helpless.
verses.comment: Idol worship yields nothing; contrast with God who rewards those who seek Him (Heb. 11:6).

verses.text: Sacrifices to them may even be touched by women in their periods or at childbirth. Since you know by these things that they are not gods, do not fear them.
verses.comment: Broken vessels symbolize uselessness; Paul uses 'vessels' for people set apart for God (2 Tim. 2:21).

verses.text: Nothing can be taken from or added to them; the idols neither give nor receive.
verses.comment: Unlike God who gives all things and fills what is lacking; idols offer nothing.

verses.text: and in their temples the priests sit with their clothes torn, their heads and beards shaved, and their heads uncovered.
verses.comment: Wealth and idols cannot save, God alone is the true provider and Savior.

verses.text: They howl and shout before their gods as some do at a funeral banquet.
verses.comment: True worship is spiritual; God receives prayers as incense (Rev. 5:8).

verses.text: The priests take some of the clothing of their gods to clothe their wives and children.
verses.comment: Idols are unable to perceive the world; the living God sees all.

verses.text: Even if storms threaten them, they cannot move nor save themselves.
verses.comment: Idols are powerless in calamity. Christ calms the storm (Mark 4:39).

verses.text: They cannot bless or judge; men pray to them for mere appearances.
verses.comment: The futility of idolatry is stressed—worship must be directed to God for true blessing.

verses.text: They cannot discern injustice or bring judgment to anyone.
verses.comment: Justice belongs to God, who alone judges rightly (Psalm 96:13).

verses.text: Though carried as if sacred, their feet are held together, and they cannot walk.
verses.comment: Physical debility of idols emphasizes spiritual emptiness.

verses.text: Even if someone puts them on a platform, nothing happens; if set before them, they cannot respond.
verses.comment: Unlike God who answers prayer (Psalm 65:2), idols remain silent.

verses.text: They can neither save people from death nor rescue the weak from the mighty.
verses.comment: God alone is the Savior who delivers from death and oppression; see typology in Exodus.

verses.text: They cannot restore sight to the blind or deliver the troubled from distress.
verses.comment: Contrasts idols with Christ, who brings healing and deliverance (Matt. 11:5).

verses.text: They cannot have mercy on the widow, do good to the orphan.
verses.comment: True religion cares for widows and orphans—central in Scripture (James 1:27).

verses.text: Their likeness is as stones cut from the mountain; their worshipers will be shamed.
verses.comment: Idols carved from creation are contrasted with the Creator. Worship of them ends in shame.

verses.text: Why then must anyone think they are gods or call them gods?
verses.comment: Invites discernment—calls the reader to recognize falsehood in idolatry.

verses.text: Even the Chaldeans themselves do not respect them; when they hear someone cannot speak, they bring it to Bel and pray, asking it to speak.
verses.comment: Bel was a Babylonian god; futility of pagan practice highlighted.

verses.text: But Bel cannot answer, even though people pray that it might speak;
verses.comment: Idols’ impotence shown—true God is responsive. Christ is the incarnate Word (John 1:1).

verses.text: They will know the idols are not gods, for they can neither judge nor rescue.
verses.comment: True divine authority is marked by judgment and mercy.

verses.text: They are just wood overlaid with gold and silver; everyone will know that they are false.
verses.comment: Idols lack substance; only God possesses true glory.

verses.text: Even children mock them when they see them adorned.
verses.comment: Children’s innocence highlights the absurdity of worshiping images.

verses.text: Kings treat them as objects, not gods, and treat priests with contempt.
verses.comment: Worldly rulers recognize idols’ lack of power; only God commands true reverence.

verses.text: If the idols receive gifts and sacrifices, the priests certainly take them for themselves.
verses.comment: Human corruption occurs when worship is misdirected from God.

verses.text: Even their garments, if bright and beautiful, wear out; and they must clothe the idols anew.
verses.comment: Creation perishes, but God alone remains eternal.

verses.text: They neither feel nor see; each idol is just a wooden post covered with gold or silver.
verses.comment: Idols are insensate; contrasts with the God who is omniscient.

verses.text: Even if a storm or earthquake strikes, the idols do not notice.
verses.comment: Unlike idols, God is present and active in history.

verses.text: They cannot compare to any living creature, for they are mere statues.
verses.comment: Living beings reflect God’s creative power; idols are lifeless.

verses.text: they are like crows between heaven and earth. When fire breaks out in a temple of wooden gods overlaid with gold or silver, their priests will flee and escape, but the gods will be burned up like timbers.
verses.comment: Reiterates God’s sovereignty; only God’s will matters. See also Christ’s authority over all (Matthew 28:18).

verses.text: They are as useless as broken cisterns; neither do they speak, nor hear.
verses.comment: Broken cisterns are a metaphor for false sources of life; only God provides true living water (John 4:14).

verses.text: They cannot give riches to anyone nor answer prayer.
verses.comment: God alone provides for needs and answers prayers.

verses.text: They cannot deliver anyone from death nor rescue the poor from oppression.
verses.comment: God saves and lifts up the poor—see Christ’s ministry among the downtrodden.

verses.text: So it is better to be a king who shows his courage, or a household utensil that serves its owner’s need, than to be these false gods; better even the door of a house that protects its contents, than these false gods; better also a wooden pillar in a palace, than these false gods.
verses.comment: True miracles and healing are works of the living God, fulfilled in the life of Christ.

verses.text: They cannot show mercy, nor bring justice to anyone.
verses.comment: Justice and mercy only come from God; foreshadows Christ’s work on the cross.

verses.text: They are like scarecrows in a cucumber field: they guard nothing.
verses.comment: An evocative metaphor for uselessness, stressing the superiority of God’s providence.

verses.text: Their faces show no feeling, for they cannot walk.
verses.comment: Senselessness again draws contrast with the living God’s responsiveness.

verses.text: Even from threats they cannot flee or save themselves by escape.
verses.comment: Helplessness of idols contrasted with God’s deliverance.

verses.text: If someone pours oil or shrouds them with incense, they do not smell it.
verses.comment: Idols cannot participate in worship; God receives the offering of the faithful.

verses.text: Even though they are decorated with gold and silver, if someone removes their clothing, they do not protest.
verses.comment: Passivity and powerlessness contrasts with God’s active care for His people.

verses.text: They are like stones from the quarry; nothing they do is useful.
verses.comment: Carved idols fail to reflect the image of the true God.

verses.text: Their eyes are full of dust, and anyone who worships them will be ashamed.
verses.comment: Shame is a frequent result for those who trust in idols; faith in the true God brings hope and honor.

verses.text: Therefore, do not fear them.
verses.comment: Final exhortation repeating the theme: only God deserves awe and reverence.

verses.text: For they cannot curse kings nor bless them.
verses.comment: God establishes and dethrones rulers (Daniel 2:21); idols have no authority.

verses.text: They cannot show signs in the sky, nor shine like the sun or the moon.
verses.comment: God alone creates and controls heavenly bodies (Genesis 1:14-16; see Christ’s power in nature, Mark 4:39).

verses.text: They cannot reveal the stars nor guide them in their course.
verses.comment: Job emphasizes God’s sovereignty over the constellations. Idols are impotent before God’s wisdom.

verses.text: They cannot give answers, nor deliver judgments.
verses.comment: True justice is from God, not images.

verses.text: Better, therefore, is someone upright who has no idols; such a person will be far above reproach.
verses.comment: The chapter closes with a final command not to fear idols—a central biblical principle. The spiritual meaning prefigures the Church's insistence on exclusive worship of the one true God. This passage also hints at the necessity of apostolic tradition that safeguards correct worship, linking true faith to the revealed worship established by God. The emphasis on exclusivity of worship and the futility of idols points toward the fullness of faith found in the continuity of apostolic teaching and those sacraments established directly by Christ Himself.

sections.title: The Exile and Promise of Return
